case_name: City Municipality v. Government of Bombay

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 211 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 211 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 19, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 976 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 19, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil application No. 976 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 21, 1961 by Sarkar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961, December 21. The Judgment of Sinha C. J., Sarkar, Das Gupta and Mudholkar JJ., was delivered by Sarkar J.

facts.text: Appellant is a City Municipality within the meaning of the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901 and is governed by that Act.

anchor.surface_text: SARKAR J.-The appellant is a City Municipality within the meaning of the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901 and is governed by that Act.

facts.text: Appellant Municipality passed a resolution under s. 60 selecting octroi tax of -/4/- annas per Bengali maund on milk brought within octroi limits for consumption, use or sale therein.

anchor.surface_text: It had by a resolution duly passed by it, made a rule under s. 60 of the Act selecting for the purpose of an octroi tax of -/4/- annas per Bengali maund, milk brought within its octroi limits for companysumption, use or sale therein.

facts.text: Government of Bombay gave sanction to the rule on November 29, 1954 under s. 61.

anchor.surface_text: On November 29, 1954, the Government of Bombay had given its sanction to the rule under s. 61 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant Municipality published the rule and sanction as required by s. 62 and imposed tax with effect from January 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Municipality thereafter published the rule and the sanction as required by s. 62 of the Act and the tax was accordingly imposed with effect from January 1, 1955.

facts.text: On April 4, 1955, Government of Bombay passed an order directing that the octroi tax shall not be leviable by the appellant Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: On April 4, 1955, the Government of Bombay passed an order directing that the octroi tax shall number be leviable by the appellant Municipality.

facts.text: Appellant Municipality filed a petition in the High Court at Bombay under Art. 226 challenging the validity of the order.

anchor.surface_text: This order has given rise to the present proceedings. The appellant Municipality filed a petition in the High Court at Bombay under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the validity of the order.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed the petition.

anchor.surface_text: This petition was dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant Municipality appealed to Supreme Court against High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Municipality has number companye up to this Court in appeal against the decision of the High Court.

facts.text: Procedure prescribed in sections 59, 60, 61, 62 complied with by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in companytroversy that in the present case the procedure prescribed in the sections mentioned above had been companyplied with.

facts.text: Government contention that the order was competent under s. 59.

anchor.surface_text: The Governments companytention is that the order made by it was companypetent as it was order which was authorised by s. 59, subject to which only a tax companyld be imposed by a Municipality.

facts.text: Appellant contention that general or special orders in s.59 must exist before rule framed and government has no power after sanction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Municipality does number dispute that it can impose a tax only under s. 59 but it companytents that the general or special orders mentioned in the section subject to which it has the power to impose tax, are orders which were in existence before the rule prescribing the tax was framed...

facts.text: Court holds that government's contention is well founded and order valid.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Governments companytention is well founded... We think that the challenge to the order dated April 4, 1955 is without any foundation. In our view, the order was perfectly legitimate and must be upheld.

facts.text: Government prohibited all Municipalities from levying any octroi tax on milk.

anchor.surface_text: The Government has number, it is number disputed, prohibited all Municipalities from levying any octroi tax on milk.

facts.text: Appellant claimed order discriminatory as no other municipality prohibited from collecting similar tax.

anchor.surface_text: A third objection to the validity of the order was that it was discriminatory. It was said that numberother Municipality had been prohibited from companylecting a similar tax which it had power under its rules to companylect.

facts.text: Court finds no discrimination as all municipalities stand on same footing regarding milk.

anchor.surface_text: we are on the facts satisfied that there is numberdiscrimination... Furthermore, it has number been shown to us that all Municipalities stand on the same footing with regard to milk.

facts.text: Appellant claimed order made mala fide to benefit respondent No. 2, a cooperative union dealing in milk.

anchor.surface_text: It was said that the Government had made this order to benefit respondent No. 2, a companyorative union, dealing in milk. This is a bare allegation and is number supported by facts.

facts.text: Court finds no mala fide as similar orders made for all municipalities.

anchor.surface_text: In any event, since similar orders have number been made in respect of all Municipalities within the State, numberquestion of mala fide can possibly arise.

facts.text: Ayyangar J. delivered separate judgment agreeing with order.

anchor.surface_text: AYYANGAR J.-I have had the advantage of perusing the judgment just delivered and I agree with order passed.

facts.text: No dispute that levy from January 1, 1955 was lawful as ss.59-62 requirements satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the levy of the duty by the municipality as and from January 1, 1955 was lawful because the requirements of ss. 59-62 were satisfied when the levy was made.
under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the validity of the order. This petition was dismissed by the High Court.
entitled to the benefit of Art. 14, as to which we think it unnecessary to express any opinion we are on the facts satisfied that there is nodiscrimination.

concepts.interpretation: Municipality as local authority argued to be 'State' not entitled to Art.14 protection; court does not decide, finds no discrimination on facts.

anchor.surface_text: S. 59.  1  Subject to any general or special orders the State Government may make in this behalf, any Municipality-  a  after observing the preliminary procedure required by section 60 and  b  with the sanction of the State Government in the case of City Municipalities and subject to such modifications or conditions as under section 61 the State Government in according such sanction, deems fit, may impose, for the purposes of this Act, any of the following taxes, that is to say, an octroi on animals or goods, or both, brought within the octroi limits for consumption, use or sale therein

concepts.interpretation: Imposition of tax under s.59 is subject to general or special orders of Government at any time, even after sanction under s.61 and publication; 'impose' means actual levy, not just rule-making.

anchor.surface_text: Section 46 gives power to a Municipality to make rules for various purposes as specified in the several clauses contained in it. Under cl.  i  of this section a Municipality has power to make rules for the purpose of prescribing, subject to the provisions of Chapter VII, the taxes to be levied.

In any event, since similar orders have now been made in respect of all Municipalities within the State, no question of mala fide can possibly arise.

issues.text: Whether the State Government has power under s.59 to issue general or special orders controlling or prohibiting the imposition of tax after the Municipality has framed the rule under s.60 and obtained sanction under s.61

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Municipality does not dispute that it can impose a tax only under s. 59 but it contends that the general or special orders mentioned in the section subject to which it has the power to impose tax, are orders which were in existence before the rule prescribing the tax was framed and once a rule has been framed by it and the Government has accorded its sanction to that rule, the Government has n

issues.text: Whether the general or special orders referred to in s.59 are those that can be made under s.73

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri for the appellant said that the general or special orders in s. 59 refer to orders that can be made under s. 73, but the present order had admittedly not been made under that section.

issues.text: Whether the order prohibiting levy of octroi on milk was discriminatory

anchor.surface_text: A third objection to the validity of the order was that it was discriminatory. It was said that no other Municipality had been prohibited from collecting a similar tax which it had power under its rules to collect.

issues.text: Whether the Municipality is a 'State' and entitled to protection under Article 14

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the very interesting question raised by the learned Attorney General that the Municipality being a local authority, was a state, and was not therefore entitled to the benefit of Art. 14, as to which we think it unnecessary to express any opinion

issues.text: Whether the Government order was passed mala fide

anchor.surface_text: The last objection was that the order had been mala fide made. This grievance is completely without foundation... It was said that the Government had made this order to benefit respondent No. 2

arguments.claim: The order made by the Government was competent as it was authorised by s. 59, subject to which only a tax could be imposed by a Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: The Governments contention is that the order made by it was competent as it was order which was authorised by s. 59, subject to which only a tax could be imposed by a Municipality.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: When the municipality levies the tax in the sense of quantifying it with reference to an ascertained person and thereby creating a statutory debt paya

arguments.court_reasoning: Government's contention well founded; imposition under s.59 subject always to general or special orders even after sanction.

arguments.claim: General or special orders in s.59 must be in existence before the rule prescribing the tax was framed; Government has no power after sanction to control imposition by s.59 order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Municipality does not dispute that it can impose a tax only under s. 59 but it contends that the general or special orders mentioned in the section subject to which it has the power to impose tax, are orders which were in existence before the rule prescribing the tax was framed and once a rule has been framed by it and the Government has accorded its sanction to that rule, the Government has no power to control the imposition of tax under it by any order made under s. 59.

arguments.court_reasoning: Impose means actual levy after rule and sanction, subject to orders; s.61 sanction different from s.59 orders; s.62 confirms actual imposition from specified date.

arguments.claim: The Municipality's power to impose tax under s.59 arises subject always to general or special orders of Government.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Governments contention is well founded. The Municipalitys power to tax arises only under s. 59. Under that section, it has been given the power of impose a tax after following the procedure prescribed but subject always to the general or special orders of the Government.

arguments.claim: Word 'impose' in s.59 does not mean acquisition of power by following ss.60-62 procedure but actual levy thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Municipality can succeed in this appeal only if the word impose in s. 59 means the acquisition of the power to tax by following the procedure laid down in ss. 60 to 62. Its appeal must otherwise fail. It seems to us that the word impose in s. 59 has not the meaning for which the appellant Municipality contends.

arguments.claim: Control via s.61 sanction different from control by general/special orders in s.59.

anchor.surface_text: It is plain from s. 59 that the control over a Municipalitys power to tax imposed by the requirement of the Governments sanction of the rule prescribing the tax contained in s. 61, is not the same thing as the control contemplated by the general or special orders mentioned in s. 59, for both are mentioned in s. 59.

arguments.claim: Imposition under s.59 happens after s.60 procedure; not passing of resolutions.

anchor.surface_text: The imposition contemplated by s. 59 is clearly not the passing of the resolutions under s. 60 selecting the tax and making the rule prescribing the tax to be levied in terms of s. 46 i , for s. 59 1 a expressly makes the imposition something happening after s. 60 has been complied with.

arguments.claim: Under s.62, 'impose' means actual levy from date specified, not acquisition of power.

anchor.surface_text: The third reason is to be found in s. 62. As we have earlier stated, it provides that the tax shall be imposed from the date mentioned in the notice publishing the sanctioned rule. ... Therefore, the word impose in s. 62 does not refer to the acquisition of power to levy a tax by making the rule but to the actual levy of the tax under the power so acquired.

arguments.claim: General or special orders in s.59 refer to orders under s.73.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri for the appellant said that the general or special orders in s. 59 refer to orders that can be made under s. 73, but the present order had admittedly not been made under that section.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: numberscope for the exercise of the State Government to make any special order in relation to a tax after it has once been imposed because the power t

arguments.court_reasoning: s.73 only suspends till objections removed, not prohibit altogether; does not limit s.59 orders.

arguments.claim: The order prohibiting octroi on milk is discriminatory as no other municipality prohibited.

anchor.surface_text: A third objection to the validity of the order was that it was discriminatory. It was said that no other Municipality had been prohibited from collecting a similar tax which it had power under its rules to collect.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: enhance any existing tax in such manner or to such extent as the Provincial Government companysiders fit, and the Municipality shall forthwith procee

arguments.court_reasoning: Government prohibited all municipalities from levying octroi on milk; all stand on same footing.

arguments.claim: Municipality as local authority is 'State' not entitled to Art.14 protection.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the very interesting question raised by the learned Attorney General that the Municipality being a local authority, was a state, and was not therefore entitled to the benefit of Art. 14,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: enhance any existing tax in such manner or to such extent as the Provincial Government companysiders fit, and the Municipality shall forthwith procee

arguments.claim: The order was made mala fide to benefit respondent No. 2, a cooperative union dealing in milk.

anchor.surface_text: It was said that the Government had made this order to benefit respondent No. 2, a cooperative union, dealing in milk. This is a bare allegation and is not supported by facts.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n made by it under this section, and the levy of tax or the enhancement, except as to arrears theretofore accrued due. shall thereupon cease or be mod

arguments.court_reasoning: Bare allegation without facts; similar orders made for all municipalities; earlier request to drop tax not mala fide.

arguments.claim: Government power under s.59 not exhausted after municipality imposes tax in conformity with then-existing orders.

anchor.surface_text: The argument strenuously pressed by Mr. Visvanatha Sastri was this The Government had nodoubt, a power to prescribe and control by general or special orders the right of a municipality to impose a tax. ... but the exercise of the power of modification or this power too prescribe conditions and restrictions is exhausted when a municipality does, by complying to the orders then in force, impose a levy which has come into force under s. 62.

arguments.court_reasoning: Nothing in language warrants exhaustion; limitation not deduced from ss.59-62.

arguments.claim: s.73 limited to suspending levy for anomalies/hardships, does not negative s.59 power to prohibit altogether.
Imposition of tax is a continuing power; levy exercises the imposition power.
Opening words of s.59(1) clothe Government with power to direct desist from tax if public interest requires.

holdings.text: The Government's contention that the order was competent under s.59 even after sanction under s.61 is well founded; the order prohibiting the octroi tax is valid and must be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Governments contention is well founded. The Municipalitys power to tax arises only under s. 59. Under that section, it has been given the power of impose a tax after following the procedure prescribed but subject always to the general or special orders of the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Municipality's power to impose tax under s.59 arises subject always to general or special orders of Government; 'impose' refers to actual levy after ss.60-62 procedure, not rule-making; s.61 sanction distinct from s.59 control.

holdings.text: The word 'impose' in s.59 means the actual levy of the tax after acquiring authority via rules and sanction, not the framing of rules or acquisition of power.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Municipality can succeed in this appeal only if the word impose in s. 59 means the acquisition of the power to tax by following the procedure laid down in ss. 60 to 62. Its appeal must otherwise fail. It seems to us that the word impose in s. 59 has not the meaning for which the appellant Municipality contends.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.59(a) places imposition after s.60 procedure; s.62 ties imposition to levy date post-sanction; contrasts with 'levied' in s.46.

holdings.text: Control via Government sanction under s.61 is distinct from control by general or special orders under s.59.

anchor.surface_text: It is plain from s. 59 that the control over a Municipalitys power to tax imposed by the requirement of the Governments sanction of the rule prescribing the tax contained in s. 61, is not the same thing as the control contemplated by the general or special orders mentioned in s. 59, for both are mentioned in s. 59.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both controls mentioned separately in s.59; s.61 sanction would render s.59 orders redundant if same.

holdings.text: General or special orders under s.59 are not limited to those under s.73; s.73 does not interpret or restrict s.59.

anchor.surface_text: Because s. 73 gives a power to suspend the tax, it is, in our opinion, no argument that the general or special orders in s. 59 must be understood as confined to such orders. Section 73 cannot help in interpreting the words general or special orders in s. 59.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.73 limited to temporary suspension for objections/anomalies; does not authorize or limit outright prohibition under s.59.

holdings.text: The order is not discriminatory as Government prohibited all municipalities from levying octroi on milk and all stand on same footing.

anchor.surface_text: we are on the facts satisfied that there is no discrimination. The Government has not, it is not disputed, prohibited all Municipalities from levying any octroi tax on milk. Furthermore, it has not been shown to us that all Municipalities stand on the same footing with regard to milk.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniform prohibition applies to all; no evidence of differential treatment shown.

holdings.text: Unnecessary to decide whether municipality as local authority is 'State' not entitled to Art.14 protection.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the very interesting question raised by the learned Attorney General that the Municipality being a local authority, was a state, and was not therefore entitled to the benefit of Art. 14, as to which we think it unnecessary to express any opinion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue avoided as no discrimination found on facts anyway.

holdings.text: The order was not made mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: This grievance is completely without foundation... In any event, since similar orders have now been made in respect of all Municipalities within the State, no question of mala fide can possibly arise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bare allegation unsupported by facts; uniform application to all municipalities precludes mala fides.

holdings.text: Imposition of a tax is a continuing power; levy exercises the imposition power, subject to ongoing government orders under s.59.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ongoing levy derives from continuing imposition authority; withdrawal of power ends imposition; supported by ss.74,47 scheme of control.

holdings.text: Opening words of s.59(1) empower Government to direct municipality to desist from tax if public interest requires.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Fills gap for public interest intervention; consistent with overall supervisory scheme in Act.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly dismiss the appeal with costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; challenge to the Government order dated April 4, 1955 upheld as legitimate.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Governments contention is well founded. The Municipalitys power to tax arises only under s. 59. Under that section, it has been given the power of impose a tax after following the procedure prescribed but subject always to the general or special orders of the Government.
We accordingly dismiss the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Municipality can succeed in this appeal only if the word impose in s. 59 means the acquisition of the power to tax by following the procedure laid down in ss. 60 to 62. Its appeal must otherwise fail. It seems to us that the word impose in s. 59 has not the meaning for which the appellant Municipality contends.
We accordingly dismiss the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: r tax which it had power under its rules to companylect. Apart from the very interesting question raised by the learned Attorney General that the Muni

edges.explanation: Distinction between s.61 sanction and s.59 orders addresses the issue of ongoing government control under s.59.

anchor.surface_text: It is plain from s. 59 that the control over a Municipalitys power to tax imposed by the requirement of the Governments sanction of the rule prescribing the tax contained in s. 61, is not the same thing as the control contemplated by the general or special orders mentioned in s. 59, for both are mentioned in s. 59.
We accordingly dismiss the appeal with costs.

edges.explanation: h4 holds s.59 orders not limited to s.73, directly resolving i2.

anchor.surface_text: Because s. 73 gives a power to suspend the tax, it is, in our opinion, no argument that the general or special orders in s. 59 must be understood as confined to such orders. Section 73 cannot help in interpreting the words general or special orders in s. 59.
We accordingly dismiss the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: we are on the facts satisfied that there is no discrimination. The Government has not, it is not disputed, prohibited all Municipalities from levying any octroi tax on milk. Furthermore, it has not been shown to us that all Municipalities stand on the same footing with regard to milk.
We accordingly dismiss the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: This grievance is completely without foundation... In any event, since similar orders have now been made in respect of all Municipalities within the State, no question of mala fide can possibly arise.
We accordingly dismiss the appeal with costs.
